The court considered the prayer offered before each city council meeting in Greece , New York , a small town outside of Rochester .
The process included neither a formal attempt to recruit clergy representing diverse faiths , nor did it require the prayers to be ecumenical .

For the first several years the prayers were delivered exclusively by Christian clergy .

The plaintiffs alleged that because the prayers invoked contained explicitly Christian theology , they amounted to a government endorsement of Christianity over other faiths , thus violating the Establishment Clause .

Justice Anthony Kennedy , writing for a 5-4 majority , held the prayer policy to be constitutional .
